Directions

This simulation shows how the heat of reaction changes with temperature. The blue line represents the enthalpy of the reactants at a given temperature, and the green line represents the enthalpy of the products at a given temperature. The black arrow between the two lines represents the heat of reaction, with the value for ΔHrxn written on top of the black arrow. Choose a different set of reactants/products using the drop-down menu labelled "Reaction". Change the temperature of the reaction using the slider labelled "Temperature". A more detailed explanation of the governing equations is given by pressing the "Details" button.

Details

The heat of reaction is a temperature-dependent property. It can be calculated from the standard heat of reaction \( H_{rxn}^{ ^{ ⊖ } } \) and the temperature-dependent heat capacities \( c_{p, i} \) where \( i \) is a component of the reaction. Standard heat of reaction \( H_{rxn}^{ ^{ ⊖ } } \) is the reaction enthalpy at 25° C (298 K) and can be calculated from standard heats of formation \( H_{f,i}^{ \circ } \). Heat of reaction at temperature \( T \) is defined:

$$ \Delta H_{rxn} = \Delta H_{rxn}^{ ^{ ⊖ } } + \int_{298}^{T} \Delta C_{p} dT $$

where the total heat capacity \( C_{p} \) is defined

$$ \Delta C_{p} = \sum_{i}^{n} \nu_{i} c_{p, i} $$

and \( \nu_{i} \) is the stoichiometric coefficient of component \( i \), and \( n \) is the number of components in the reaction. The heat capacity is often approximated using the Shomate equation:

$$ c_{p, i} = A + BT + CT^{2} + DT^{3} + \frac{ E }{ T^{2} } $$

where the coefficients \( A \), \( B \), \( C \), \( D \), and \( E \) are determined experimentally, and \( T \) is temperature in Kelvin. The resulting algebraic formula for heat of reaction \( \Delta H_{rxn} \) is therefore

$$ \Delta H_{rxn} = \Delta H_{rxn}^{ ^{ ⊖ } } + \sum_{i}^{n} \left[ \nu_{i} A_{i} (T - 298) + \frac{ \nu_{i} B_{i} }{ 2 } ( T^{2} - 298^{2} ) + \frac{ \nu_{i} C_{i} }{ 3 } ( T^{3} - 298^{3} ) + \frac{ \nu_{i} D_{i} }{ 4 } ( T^{4} - 298^{4} ) - \frac{ \nu_{i} E_{i} }{ T } + \frac{ \nu_{i} E_{i} }{ 298 } \right] $$
